results.title: Instinct
results.creator_credit: Brenda Horsfield, James McCloy and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Man in the Making”.
The relationship between animal mothers and their young is built up by a series of complex instinctive responses, and today some scientists see similar kinds of behaviour patterns in human mothers and babies. The first almost automatic smile of a baby may be a simple instinctive action which plays an important part in its development. Children reared in an institution tend to lapse into a state of withdrawal. Speakers include: Dr Mavis Gunther, Dr R.A. Hinde and Dr J.A. Ambrose.

results.title: Instant arson: testing firebombs and incendiaries
results.brief_description: Discusses the effects of arson with firebombs and chemical incendiaries as ignition sources, and demonstrates different methods of extinguishing the resulting fire.

results.title: Installing trim
results.brief_description: Carpenter Craig Savage considers that trimwork, being the most visible part of your house, should get the attention they deserve. As he trims out parts of a house, his step-by-step instructions and trade secrets will guide you on how to achieve professional results. Included in this video are demonstrations on how to make a tight butt, miter or cope joint, negotiate unsquare openings, seat mouldings solidly against bumpy walls and ceilings, extend window and door jambs and fit casing around doors and windows.

results.title: Installing doors and windows
results.brief_description: Carpenter Tom Law demonstrates his methods for installing doors and windows using easy to follow techniques and hints that he has developed over 26 years. You will be instructed on the installation of various doors and windows, each requiring different skills that you will build on and develop with each application. Among the skills are squaring and securing an opening window, building and installing a jamb, hanging and adjusting a door.

results.title: Inspired design and costume sketches
results.brief_description: Costume designers don’t always rely on sketches of their creations. True History of the Kelly Gang designer Alice Babidge sketches to distil references, while Judy & Punch designer Edie Kurzer gets more inspiration from objects.

constellations_primary.name: Inspired design and costume sketches
constellations_primary.description: Costume designers Edie Kurzer and Alice Babidge have worked on some of the most acclaimed Australian and international films and TV, joining the ranks of fellow Australians creatives.

results.description:
Judy & Punch (2019) costume designer Edie Kurzer often explores mood and atmosphere with images instead of using them as direct influences. While she may use sketches to work through details, she gains more inspiration from objects like feathers, buttons or fabrics, and then works with a fabric cutter, in this case Justine Coultham, who sketches how the costume should be cut and assembled.   

Rather than draw what the finished costume should look like, True History of the Kelly Gang (2019) costume designer Alice Babidge uses sketches to distil various reference images into one thought. For Babidge, drawing helps “refine an idea”, while the torn faces on the photos help the actors imagine how they’ll inhabit the character.
description_for_label:
Judy & Punch (2019) costume designer Edie Kurzer often explores mood and atmosphere with images instead of using them as direct influences. While she may use sketches to work through details, she gains more inspiration from objects like feathers, buttons or fabrics, and then works with a fabric cutter, in this case Justine Coultham, who sketches how the costume should be cut and assembled.   

Rather than draw what the finished costume should look like, True History of the Kelly Gang (2019) costume designer Alice Babidge uses sketches to distil various reference images into one thought. For Babidge, drawing helps “refine an idea”, while the torn faces on the photos help the actors imagine how they’ll inhabit the character.

results.title: Inspired by veterans
results.creator_credit: Hugh Melville, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: So keen was Hugh Melville to join his older brother in the second world war, that he deliberately failed first year Medicine to achieve his goal. While Hugh travelled extensively and fought in different countries, it was the men he fought with that were an inspiration to him, back then and for the rest of his life.

results.title: Inspired
results.brief_description:
Aaron Purnell used to suffer with up to 200 seizures a day. When he elected to have an operation that would stop his seizures, Aaron also knew that he would also end up with a permanent disability. This is his story of living with that disability, his involvement with the Whitehorse Disability Awareness Project and how his best friend Alisha inspired him to make something of his life.
This project was funded by the Department of Human Services, (Eastern Metropolitan Region), developed and executed in partnership with MetroAccess at the City of Monash and City of Whitehorse, and Scope.
